{{pp-blp|expiry=22:40, 30 August 2019|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}}{{Infobox musical artist | name = 21 Savage | image = 21 Savage 2018.jpg | caption = 21 Savage performing in Austin, Texas in June 2018. | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Shayaa Bin Abraham-Joseph | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1992|10|22|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]], U.S. | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] * [[Trap music|trap]] * [[gangsta rap]] }} | occupation = {{flatlist| * Rapper * singer * songwriter * record producer }} | instrument = Vocals | years_active = {{start date|2014}}–present | label = {{flatlist| * Slaughter Gang * [[Epic Records|Epic]] }} | associated_acts = {{flatlist| * [[Metro Boomin]] * [[Offset (rapper)|Offset]] * [[Southside (record producer)|Southside]] * [[Sonny Digital]] * [[Zaytoven]] }} | website = {{URL|21savage.com}} }}
'''Shayaa Bin Abraham-Joseph''' (born October 22, 1992), better known by his stage name '''21 Savage''', is an American [[rapper]], record producer, and songwriter from [[Atlanta, Georgia]]. Abraham-Joseph grew up around criminality and eventually dropped out of school, beginning to rap in 2013 after the death of a friend. He gained attention in the [[Atlanta]] underground for the 2015 mixtape ''[[The Slaughter Tape]]'' before attaining nationwide attention following the [[Metro Boomin]] collaborative album ''[[Savage Mode]]'' (2016), its lead single "[[X (21 Savage and Metro Boomin song)|X]]", and his collaboration with Drake, "[[Sneakin']]".<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.interviewmagazine.com/music/21-savage-seth-rogen-interview|title=21 Savage chops it up with Seth Rogen|date=2018-04-26|work=Interview Magazine|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en-US}}</ref>
Abraham-Joseph released his debut studio album, ''[[Issa Album]]'', in 2017<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/the-break/2015/10/the-break-presents-21-savage/|title=The Break Presents: 21 Savage|last=C.M.|first=Emmanuel|date=October 9, 2015|work=[[XXL (magazine)|XXL Magazine]]|accessdate=May 2, 2018}}</ref> which debuted at number two on the ''Billboard'' 200 and gave Abraham-Joseph his first top twenty song, "[[Bank Account (song)|Bank Account]]." He achieved his first number one single at the end of 2017 with his feature on [[Post Malone]]'s "[[Rockstar (Post Malone song)|Rockstar]]."<ref name="XXL Magazine2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2017/10/post-malone-21-savage-rockstar-no-1-billboard-hot-100-chart/|title=Post Malone's ''Rockstar'' Hits No. 1 on Billboard Hot 100 Chart|website=XXL Magazine|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> In 2017, he also released the [[Offset (rapper)|Offset]] and Metro Boomin collaboration ''[[Without Warning (21 Savage, Offset and Metro Boomin album)|Without Warning]]''.
==Early life== Shayaa Bin Abraham-Joseph was born on October 22, 1992, in Atlanta, Georgia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/21-savage-mn0003515232/biography|title=Biography & History|last=Jeffries|first=David|website=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=February 22, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Birthplace2">{{cite web|url=https://schedule.sxsw.com/2016/events/event_MS37401|title=21 Savage|author=<!--Not stated-->|website=[[South by Southwest]]|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> He was raised by his mother Heather, who is of [[People of Dominica|Dominica]] descent, and his four brothers and six sisters, though one is deceased due to a shooting after a [[Illegal drug trade|drug deal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://djbooth.net/features/2016-11-22-brutal-story-behind-21-savage-dagger-face-tattoo|title=The Brutal Story Behind 21 Savage's Dagger Face Tattoo|last=James|first=Andy|date=November 22, 2018|website=[[DJBooth]]|access-date=May 2, 2018|quote=}}</ref>
In the seventh grade, Abraham-Joseph was banned permanently from every school in the [[DeKalb County School District]] due to gun possession.<ref>{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v1CmVcwIyKo|title=21 Savage Interview With The Breakfast Club (8-4-16)|date=August 4, 2016|people=[[Charlamagne tha God]], [[DJ Envy]]|publisher=[[The Breakfast Club (radio show)]]|location=[[New York City]]|access-date=May 6, 2018|medium=Video}}</ref> This led him to begin attending schools around the [[Atlanta metropolitan area]] before being sent to a youth detention center.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/everything-you-need-to-know-about-21-savage-news.22853.html|title=Everything You Need To Know About 21 Savage|work=HotNewHipHop|access-date=2017-08-24}}</ref> After being released from the youth detention center, he completed eighth grade through an alternative program before finishing a semester of high school, dropping out in his freshman year following multiple exclusions which Abraham-Joseph said he was "exhausted" by.<ref name=":02">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thefader.com/2016/08/04/21-savage-the-breakfast-club-interview|title=21 Savage Talks Being An "A" Student, Losing His Best Friends On The Breakfast Club|work=The FADER|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref>
After dropping out, Abraham-Joseph joined a gang affiliated with the [[Bloods]]<ref name=":2" /> and became a full-time drug dealer, mainly selling cannabis.<ref name=":02" /> He also took parts in other criminal activities including robbery and grand theft auto regularly, though only being arrested once after contraband was found in a car he was driving.<ref name=":12">{{Cite news|url=https://www.gq.com/story/21-savage-profile-2018|title=21 Savage: From Robbin’ Season to Role Model|last=Wood|first=Samuel Hine, Geordie|date=2018-06-27|work=GQ|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> In 2011, when Abraham-Joseph was 19, he lost his "right hand" man, Larry in a shootout.<ref name=":02" /> In 2013, on his 21st birthday, Abraham-Joseph was shot six times and his brother Johnny "Tay-Man" was killed during an attempted robbery.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2015/10/01/feature-21-savage|title=Meet 21 Savage, Atlanta’s Most Respected New Rapper|website=[[The Fader]]|access-date=August 24, 2017}}</ref>
==Career== ===2014–15: Early releases=== Following the death of his friend in a shootout on his 21st birthday, Abraham-Joseph began rapping, naming himself after the event<ref name=":12" /> though Savage came from Instagram predictions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.capitalxtra.com/features/facts/21-savage/|title=19 Facts You Need To Know About 'Rockstar' Rapper 21 Savage|work=Capital XTRA|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> His music career was originally subsidized by the uncle of his deceased friend, giving him money for studio time in 2013.<ref name=":2" /> On November 12, 2014, 21 Savage's debut single, "Picky", produced by DJ Plugg, was released. It was later included on his debut mixtape, ''[[The Slaughter Tape]]'', which was released on May 25, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livemixtapes.com/mixtapes/34127/21-savage-the-slaughter-tape.html|title=21 Savage - The Slaughter Tape|work=LiveMixtapes|accessdate=April 27, 2016}}</ref> The release made him what [[Interview (magazine)|Interview]] called an "underground hero in Atlanta."<ref name=":2" />
On July 2, 2015, 21 released a collaborative EP, ''Free Guwop'', with [[Sonny Digital]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livemixtapes.com/mixtapes/35036/21-savage-free-guwop-ep.html|title=21 Savage - Free Guwop EP|work=LiveMixtapes|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref> It is a tribute EP to fellow rapper and influence [[Gucci Mane]]. On December 1, 2015, Abraham-Joseph released his second mixtape, ''[[Slaughter King]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/21-savage-slaughter-king-new-mixtape.116157.html|title=21 Savage - Slaughter King - Download & Listen [New Mixtape]|author=Rose Lilah|date=2 December 2015|work=HotNewHipHop|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref>
===2016–present: ''Savage Mode'', ''Issa Album'' and ''Without Warning''=== [[File:21 Savage 2018 2.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:21%20Savage%202018%202.jpg|left|thumb|21 Savage in June 2018]] In June 2016, Abraham-Joseph was named as one of the "Freshman Class" of 2016 by ''[[XXL (magazine)|XXL]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2016/06/xxl-freshman-class-cover-2016/|title=XXL Freshman Class Cover 2016|last=|first=|date=June 13, 2016|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=[[Townsquare Media]]|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref> On July 15, 2016, Abraham-Joseph released his joint [[Extended play|EP]] [[Savage Mode]] with Atlanta-based record producer [[Metro Boomin]]. The EP gained international success and peaked at number 23 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], which became their highest charting EP to date.<ref name="BB2002">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/7447109/21-savage/chart|title=21 Savage – Chart History: Billboard 200|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=July 29, 2016}}</ref> He was on the cover of [[Fader (magazine)|''Fader'']].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/21-savage-and-futures-x-is-now-platinum-news.25668.html|title=21 Savage on the cover of Fader|last=Lilah|first=Rose|access-date=23 November 2016}}</ref> His single "[[X (21 Savage and Metro Boomin song)|X]]" featuring [[Future (rapper)|Future]] on the EP was confirmed by Billboard as going platinum in the US, being 21's 1st platinum record.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2016/11/21-savage-first-platinum-record-x/|title=21 Savage Gets His First Platinum Record With "X"|last=Weinstein|first=Max|date=November 22, 2016|website=|publisher=|accessdate=December 3, 2016}}</ref> On January 18, 2017, Abraham-Joseph announced that he had signed to [[Epic Records]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/news/id.42064/title.21-savage-inks-record-deal-with-epic-records#|title=21 Savage Inks Record Deal With Epic Records|accessdate=January 18, 2017}}</ref>
In 2017, his debut studio album, ''[[Issa Album]]'', reached at number two on the US ''Billboard'' 200 chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7866158/21-savage-haim-billboard-200-albums-chart-top-10|title=21 Savage & Haim Debut in Top 10 on Billboard 200 Albums Chart|last=Caulfield|first=Keith|date=July 16, 2017|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=July 17, 2017}}</ref> Its lead single, "[[Bank Account (song)|Bank Account]]", charted in the top 20 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://headlineplanet.com/home/2017/08/08/hot-100-niall-horans-slow-hands-enters-top-15-21-savages-bank-account-top-20/|title=Hot 100: Niall Horan’s "Slow Hands" Enters Top 15, 21 Savage’s "Bank Account" Top 20|date=August 7, 2017|work=Headline Planet|access-date=August 9, 2017}}</ref> Later that year, he was featured on [[Post Malone]]'s single "[[Rockstar (Post Malone song)|Rockstar]]", which peaked at number one on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, and broke several records.<ref name="XXL Magazine2" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/01/post-malone-rockstar-breaks-spotify-global-record/|title=Post Malone Breaks Spotify Global Record With ''Rockstar'' - XXL|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=Townsquare Media|access-date=2018-02-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8031270/post-malone-rockstar-platinum-21-savage|title=Post Malone & 21 Savage's 'Rockstar' Is Now Certified Platinum|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-02-16}}</ref>
In April 2018, Abraham-Joseph had a guest appearance on [[Young Thug]]'s extended play ''[[Hear No Evil (Young Thug EP)|Hear No Evil]]'' along with fellow rappers [[Nicki Minaj]] and [[Lil Uzi Vert]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2018/04/13/young-thug-hear-no-evil-nicki-minaj-21-savage|title=Young Thug drops Hear No Evil EP|last=Maicki|first=Salvatore|date=April 13, 2018|website=The Fader|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref> Later that month he also appeared on the single "Outstanding" by [[SahBabii]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/new-music/2018/04/sahbabii-21-savage-new-song-outstanding/|title=Listen to SahBabii and 21 Savage's New Song "Outstanding"|last=India|first=Lindsey|date=April 20, 2018|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=Townsquare Media|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> In March 21 he was featured on the single "Rover 2.0", which is part of [[BlocBoy JB]]'s [[Simi (mixtape)|Simi]] mixtape.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.stereogum.com/1988300/blocboy-jb-rover-2-0-feat-21-savage/music/|title=BlocBoy JB – "Rover 2.0" (Feat. 21 Savage)|last=Breihan|first=Tom|date=March 23, 2018|website=[[Stereogum]]|publisher=[[Eldridge Industries]]|access-date=May 1, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/new-music/2018/05/blocboy-jb-simi-mixtape/|title=BlocBoy JB Drops 'Simi' Mixtape Featuring Drake, Lil Pump and More|last=Coleman II|first=C. Vernon|date=May 4, 2018|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=Townsquare Media|access-date=May 9, 2018}}</ref> In the following month, he was featured on [[Ty Dolla Sign]]'s "Clout", which is part of the upcoming deluxe edition of last years's ''[[Beach House 3]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Darville|first=Jordan|date=May 9, 2018|title=Ty Dolla $ign recruits 21 Savage for "Clout"|url=http://www.thefader.com/2018/05/09/ty-dolla-sign-21-savage-clout|magazine=The Fader|location=New York City|access-date=May 11, 2018}}</ref>
On October 31, 2018, [[Halloween]], Abraham-Joseph posted on his Instagram a picture of a man in silhouette jumping in the air in the direction away from a large blaze. In the bottom right corner of the picture there is a "Parental Advisory" notice, as there oftentimes is on the cover of rap releases. Abraham-Joseph also tagged Metro Boomin in the post. For these reasons, some speculated it to be a sequel to 2017's ''Without Warning'' record. However, it turned out to be the cover for Metro’s debut solo album, ''[[Not All Heroes Wear Capes]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BpnfcqeBtAT/?hl=en&taken-by=21savage|title=Saint Laurent Don on Instagram: "y’all know what season it is @metroboomin 4L"|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2018-11-01}}</ref>
== Musical style == Called "one of the last street niggas left making music" by frequent collaborator Metro Boomin,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thefader.com/2015/10/01/feature-21-savage|title=Meet 21 Savage, Atlanta’s Most Respected New Rapper|work=The FADER|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> Abraham-Joseph's music is heavily autobiographic with emphasis on violent and criminal aspects of his past including murder and drug dealing.<ref name=":12" />
==Controversies== In 2018, 21 Savage reportedly started a movement called "Guns Down, Paintballs Up" which was intended to reduce gun violence.<ref name="CBS2">{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/paintball-wars-initially-intended-to-curb-gun-violence-linked-to-2-deaths/|title="Paintball wars," initially intended to curb gun violence, linked to 2 deaths|last=Diaz|first=Adriana|date=May 1, 2018|website=[[CBS News]]|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> The head of the [[Detroit Police Department]], [[James Craig (police chief)|James Craig]], described the movement as "well-intentioned, however, misguided".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/paint-up-guns-down-detroit-paintball-arrests-2018-04-27/|title=Detroit police cracks down on citywide "paintball wars"|author=<!--Not stated-->|date=April 21, 2018|website=CBS News|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2018/04/27/detroit-police-crack-down-citywide-paintball-wars/560019002/|title=Detroit police to crack down on citywide 'paintball wars'|last1=Patterson|first1=Brandon|last2=Zaniewski|first2=Ann|date=April 27, 2018|website=[[USA Today]]|publisher=[[Gannett Company]]|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> The movement has been linked to several cases of property crime and homicide.<ref name="CBS2" /><ref name="USA Today2">{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2018/05/01/paintball-wars-spate-shootings/569407002/|title=Paintball shootings splatter cities after rapper calls for swapping handguns for paintball weapons|last1=Mensch|first1=Jessica|last2=Luthern|first2=Ashley|date=May 1, 2018|website=USA Today|publisher=Gannett Company|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> 21 Savage has not commented on the matter, although he paid for the funeral of a 3-year old who was killed in a related incident.<ref name="CBS2" /><ref name="USA Today2" />
Controversy arose after Abraham-Joseph pulled out a firearm during a pool party on June 11, 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8460380/21-savage-gun-atlanta-brawl|title=21 Savage Draws Gun During Atlanta Pool Party Brawl|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref> Abraham-Joseph was given the firearm by a friend after seeing an opposing crew member also pull out a pistol.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vibe.com/2018/06/21-savage-pull-out-a-gun/|title=21 Savage Pulls Out A Gun During A Brawl: Watch|date=2018-06-10|work=Vibe|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref>
==Personal life== Abraham-Joseph practices the African religion [[Ifá]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://noisey.vice.com/en_us/article/zn4pn3/21-savage-breakfast-club-interview-2016|title=No Joke, You Should Definitely Watch 21 Savage's Entire 'Breakfast Club' Interview|last=Witmer|first=Phil|date=August 4, 2016|website=[[Noisey]]|publisher=[[Vice Media]]|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2016/11/21/21-savage-cover-story-interview|title=Savage World|last=Barshad|first=Amos|date=November 21, 2016|website=The Fader|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://pulse.ng/gist/21-savage-the-hottest-rapper-in-america-worships-ifa-id5816327.html|title=21 Savage, the hottest rapper in America worships Ifa|last=Tayo|first=Ayomide O.|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref> In summer 2017, Savage started dating model [[Amber Rose]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/02/amber-rose-sniffs-21-savages-underwear/|title=Amber Rose Sniffs 21 Savage's Underwear When She Misses Him|last=Coleman II|first=C. Vernon|date=February 10, 2018|work=XXL Magazine|accessdate=February 10, 2018|publisher=Townsquare Media}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bet.com/music/2018/02/14/21-savage-valentines-day-gift-amber-rose.html|title=21 Savage Got The Sexiest Gift From Amber Rose For Valentine's Day|date=February 14, 2018|work=[[BET]]|accessdate=March 16, 2018}}</ref> As of March 2018, the couple has separated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.com/music/amber-rose-21-savage-split/|title=Amber Rose and 21 Savage Split After Nearly 2 Years of Dating|last1=Mizoguchi|first1=Karen|last2=Rubenstein|first2=Janine|date=March 14, 2018|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=March 15, 2018}}</ref>
He also has three children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.capitalxtra.com/features/facts/21-savage/does-have-kids/|title=Does 21 Savage have any kids?|author=<!--Not stated-->|website=[[Capital XTRA]]|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref>
== Filmography == 21 Savage is currently working on his first movie, "'''''Issa Movie'''''".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ballerstatus.com/2017/12/10/21-savage-delivers-trailer-issa-movie/|title=21 Savage Delivers Trailer for "ISSA" Movie|date=2017-12-10|work=BallerStatus.com|access-date=2018-11-04|language=en-US}}</ref>
21 Savage also worked on a [[YouTube]] [[miniseries]] named "'''''Year 2100'''''".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2017/06/21-savage-animated-web-series-the-year-2100/|title=21 Savage Gets Animated in New Web Series ‘The Year 2100’ - XXL|website=XXL Mag|language=en|access-date=2018-11-04}}</ref>
==Discography== {{Main|21 Savage discography}}
===Studio albums===
* ''[[Issa Album]]'' (2017) * ''[[Without Warning (21 Savage, Offset and Metro Boomin album)|Without Warning]]'' {{small|(with [[Offset (rapper)|Offset]] and [[Metro Boomin]])}} (2017)
===Extended plays===
* ''[[Free Guwop]]'' (2015) * ''[[Savage Mode]]'' {{small|(with Metro Boomin)}} (2016)
===Mixtapes===
* ''[[The Slaughter Tape]]'' (2015) * ''[[Slaughter King]]'' (2015)
==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Award !Category !Nominated Work !Result |- | rowspan="10"| 2018 | [[BET Awards 2017|BET Awards]] | [[BET Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]] | rowspan="2"|Himself | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2"| [[2018 iHeartRadio Music Awards|iHeartRadio Music Awards]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/8240363/iheartradio-music-award-winners-2018-complete-list-winners-1089542|title=iHeartRadio Music Award Winners 2018: Complete List|last=Atkinson|first=Katie|date=March 11, 2018|work=Billboard|access-date=March 11, 2018}}</ref> | Best New Hip-Hop Artist | {{nom}} |- | Hip-Hop Song of the Year | "[[Rockstar (Post Malone song)|Rockstar]]" {{small|(with [[Post Malone]])}} | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="5" |[[2018 Billboard Music Awards|''Billboard'' Music Awards]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/bbma/8343598/billboard-music-awards-2018-nominations-list|title=Billboard Music Awards 2018 Nominations: See the Full List|date=April 17, 2018|work=Billboard|access-date=April 17, 2018}}</ref> |[[Billboard Music Award for Top New Artist|Top New Artist]] |Himself |{{nom}} |- |[[Billboard Music Award for Top Hot 100 Song|Top Hot 100 Song]] | rowspan="6" | "Rockstar" {{small|(with Post Malone)}} | {{nom}} |- |[[Billboard Music Award for Top Streaming Song (Audio)|Top Streaming Song (Audio)]] | {{nom}} |- |Top Collaboration | {{nom}} |- |[[Billboard Music Award for Top Rap Song|Top Rap Song]] | {{won}} |- | [[ASCAP Awards|ASCAP Pop Awards]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/news-events/awards/2018/pop-awards|title=2018 Ascap Pop Awards|website=ASCAP|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref> | Winning Songs | {{nom}} |- | [[2018 MTV Video Music Awards|MTV Video Music Awards]] | Song of the Year | {{won}} |}

{{Infobox musical artist |image = |caption = |name = 2Play
(Wesley Johnson) |background = solo_singer |birth_name = Wesley Johnson |alias = 2Play, Wesley J, Special T |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1977|7|22}} |death_date = |origin = London, England |genre = [[Dancehall]], [[reggae]], [[contemporary R&B|R&B]], [[hip hop music|hip hop]], [[UK garage]] |occupation = Musician, record producer, songwriter, rapper |years_active = 1997–present |associated_acts = [[Raghav]], Jucxi D, [[Maxi Priest]], [[Moni]], [[Naila Boss]], Thomas Jules |website = }} {{about|the British musician|the article about a multiplayer game of two players|Two-player game|the article about a multiplayer video game|Two-player video game}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Use British English|date=July 2012}} '''Wesley Johnson''' (born 1977), known by his stage name '''2Play''',Graham Betts Complete UK Hit Albums 1956-2005 2005 - Page 330 "Raghav Mathur (bom 1983) who was educated at ... He won the 2004 MOBO Award for Best Collaboration with 2Play and Jucxi for So Confused." is a British musician, record producer, and former [[mixed martial artist]]. ==Music career== 2Play is a [[Music of Black Origin Awards|MOBO]] Award–winning record producer and musician.{{cite web|url=http://acharts.us/performer/2play|title=2play - Music Charts|publisher=}} He is best known for songs with the Canadian-Indian singer [[Raghav]], as well as collaborations with a number of artists including Jucxi D, [[Naila Boss]], Thomas Jules and Moni. 2Play first entered the music scene in 1997 as a [[UK garage]] producer under the alias Special T.{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/291524-Special-T|title=Special T|publisher=}} He has had two UK [[Top 40|Top 10]] [[hit single]]s: "So Confused" (featuring Raghav and Jucxi) and "It Can't Be Right" (featuring Raghav and Naila Boss).{{cite book | first= David | last= Roberts | year= 2006 | title= British Hit Singles & Albums | edition= 19th | publisher= Guinness World Records Limited | location= London | isbn= 1-904994-10-5 | page= 571}} A [[cover version|cover]] of [[Kevin Lyttle]]'s "[[Turn Me On (Kevin Lyttle song)|Turn Me On]]" featuring Raghav and Jucxi appeared as a B-side to the single "So Confused". In 2005, "So Confused" also won "Best Single" at the [[UK Asian Music Awards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wass-up.com/ukama2005.php |title=Artists unite to celebrate British Asian Music |accessdate=24 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110110150402/http://wass-up.com/ukama2005.php |archivedate=10 January 2011 }} He has produced cover versions of such songs as [[George Michael]]'s "[[Careless Whisper]]" (featuring Thomas Jules and Jucxi D) and [[Maxi Priest]]'s "[[Close to You (Maxi Priest song)|Close to You]]" (featuring Moni). ===Discography=== ====Singles==== {|class="wikitable" |- !rowspan="2"| Year !rowspan="2"| Single !| Chart positions !rowspan="2"| Album |- !width="30"|[[UK Singles Chart]] |- || 2003 |"So Confused" featuring [[Raghav]] and Jucxi | style="text-align:center;"| 6 |rowspan="2"| [[Storyteller (Raghav album)|Raghav album ''Storyteller'']] |- || 2004 |"It Can't Be Right" featuring [[Raghav]] and [[Naila Boss]] | style="text-align:center;"| 8 |- || 2005 |"[[Careless Whisper]]" featuring Thomas Jules and Jucxi D | style="text-align:center;"| 29 | |- || 2007 |"[[Close to You (Maxi Priest song)|Close to You]]" featuring Moni | style="text-align:center;"| – | |- || 2009 |"That's What the Girls Like" featuring [[Maxi Priest]], Moni and Jucxi D | style="text-align:center;"| – | |} ==Mixed martial arts== {{Infobox martial artist | name = Wesley Johnson | other_names = | image = | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1977|7|22|df=y}} | birth_place = London, England | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = English | height = | weight = | weight_class = [[Lightweight (MMA)|Lightweight]] | reach = | style = [[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu]], [[Karate]] | stance = | fighting_out_of = London, England | team = | rank = ''[[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu ranking system#Brown belt|brown belt]] in [[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu]]''

He fought for [[Cage Rage]] and [[Ultimate Challenge MMA]].{{cite web|author=Sherdog.com |url=http://www.sherdog.com/fighter/Wesley-Johnson-34903 |title=Wesley Johnson MMA Stats, Pictures, News, {{pp|small=yes}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = 2 Pistols | image = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Jeremy Lemont Saunders | alias = 2P | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1983|6|11}} | birth_place = [[Tarpon Springs, Florida]], United States | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | occupation = [[Rapper]] | years_active = 2006–present | label = Blood Money Union (2007–present)
[[Republic Records|Republic]] (2007–2009)
[[Ruff Ryders Entertainment|Ruff Ryders]], [[Cash Money Records|Cash Money]], [[Universal Motown|Universal]] (2009–2011) | website = }} '''Jeremy Lemont Saunders''' (born June 11, 1983),{{cite web |url=http://www.dc.state.fl.us/ActiveOffenders/ |title=Supervised Population Information Detail - Jeremy L. Saunders |publisher=[[Florida Department of Corrections]] |accessdate=February 7, 2010 }} better known by his [[stage name]] '''2 Pistols''' (censored as '''2P'''), is an American [[rapper]] and [[songwriter]]. He hails from [[Tarpon Springs, Florida]].{{cite web |url=http://www.amentertainment.com/artist-booking/2-pistols |title=Biography of 2 Pistols |accessdate=October 14, 2014 |publisher=A&M Entertainment}} He has released two albums and a number of singles and mixtapes. He signed with [[Universal Music Group|Universal]] in 2007{{cite web |url = {{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p1034303|pure_url=yes}}|title = Biography for 2 Pistols at AllMusic.com}} and his collaboration with [[T-Pain]] on the song "[[She Got It]]", which peaked at #7 on the Rhythmic Top 40 chart in 2008, and hit #2 on the Billboard Hot Rap Tracks chart.{{cite web |title = Billboard Chart information at AllMusic.com|url = {{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p1034303|pure_url=yes}}}} == Biography == From a broken home, Saunders grew up being looked after by his extended family. By his teens, he became involved in local crime and in 2005 was incarcerated for eight months. After this he became involved in music promotion and formed a group called Blood Money Union, which consisted of other DJs, producers and rappers. Saunders' first success in rapping had come with a self-released record called "Dirty Foot," which he wrote while still in high school and distributed in the [[Tarpon Springs, Florida|Tarpon Springs]] area, at the urging of his cousin. After hearing it played in a local dance club and then witnessing another rapper's performance, 2 Pistols had his first chance to perform on-stage. After taking the stage and performing his own single ("Dirty Foot"), 2 Pistols' confidence in his abilities grew to a point that he began to take his chances at making a career of music seriously. His debut album, ''[[Death Before Dishonor (album)|Death Before Dishonor]]'', was released on June 17, 2008Listing at [http://www.billboard.com/artist/431860/2-pistols/chart Billboard.com], accessed October 15, 2014. and featured production from the [[Grammy]]-winning [[J.U.S.T.I.C.E. League]], Da Honorable C.N.O.T.E, Bolo Da Producer, and others. Other tracks from the album included "You Know Me feat. Ray J" & "Thats My Word feat.Trey Songz"," in addition to "[[She Got It]]." The album peaked at #32 on the Billboard Top 200 chart, and rose to #10 on the Billboard Top R&B/Hip Hop album chart.{{cite web | title = Billboard Chart information at AllMusic.com | url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p1034303|pure_url=yes}}}} 2 Pistols resides in [[Tampa, Florida]] and currently releases his music under his own label, Blood Money Union. In February 2014, the album ''Comin Back Hard'' appeared through Stage One Music.{{Cite web|url = http://hiphopsrevival.com/2014/09/03/qa-2-pistols-talks-working-with-french-montana-his-current-deal-situations-the-florida-music-scene-more/|title = Q&A 2 Pistols talks working with French Montana, his current deal situations, the florida music-scene & more.|date = September 3, 2014|accessdate = October 15, 2014|website = Hip Hop Revival|publisher = |last = Goodwin|first = Travis|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20141021190751/http://hiphopsrevival.com/2014/09/03/qa-2-pistols-talks-working-with-french-montana-his-current-deal-situations-the-florida-music-scene-more/|archive-date = October 21, 2014|dead-url = yes|df = mdy-all}} == Discography == === Studio albums === {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" border="1" |+ List of albums, with selected chart Rap Albums|US Rap]] |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Death Before Dishonor (album)|Death Before Dishonor]]'' | * Released: June 17, 2008 * Label: [[Universal Republic Records|Universal Records]] * Format: [[Music download|digital download]] | — || — || — |- | colspan="14" style="font-size:90%" | "—" denotes items that did not chart or were not released. |} === Mixtapes === * ''The Jimmy Jump revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = 360 | image = 360 at his Falling and Flying CD signing.jpg | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = 360 at his ''Falling & Flying'' CD Signing, [[Cheltenham, Victoria|Cheltenham]], February 2012 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Matthew James Colwell | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1986|7|12|df=y}} | birth_place = | origin = [[Melbourne]], Victoria, Australia | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | occupation = Rapper, singer-songwriter | instrument = | years_active = 2006–present | label = Inertia, [[EMI Music Australia]], Soulmate, Forthwrite | associated_acts = Forthwrite, [[Diafrix]], [[Josh Pyke]], [[Gossling]], [[N'fa]], [[Pez (musician)|Pez]] | website = {{URL|360music.com.au}} }} '''Matthew James Colwell''' (born 12 July 1986), better known by his [[stage name]] '''360''', is an Australian [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] recording artist. He has released four studio albums: ''What You See Is What You Get'' (2008); ''[[Falling & Flying]]'' (2011), which peaked at No. 4 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Albums Chart]] and was certified platinum; ''Utopia'' (2014), and "Vintage modern" (2017). 360's second album provided four charting singles, including "[[Boys like You (360 song)|Boys like You]]", which peaked at No. 3 on the ARIA Singles Chart and was certified 4× platinum. At the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2012]], he received six nominations and won the '[[ARIA Award for Breakthrough Artist - Release|Breakthrough Artist – Release]]' award for ''Falling & Flying'', while Styalz Fuego won the ARIA 'Producer of the Year' Artisan award for the same album.{{cite web|author1=Nicholas Jones|title=360, Gotye Lead Nominations For 2012 ARIA Awards|url=http://www.tonedeaf.com.au/208671/360-gotye-lead-nominations-2012-aria-awards.htm|website=Tone Deaf|publisher=Tone Deaf|accessdate=21 October 2014|date=3 October 2012}} ==Early life== 360 was born on 12 July 1986.{{cite web | publisher = [[Australasian Performing Right Association]] (APRA) | title = 'Died This Way' at APRA search engine | url = http://www.apra-amcos.com.au/worksearch.axd?q=Died%20This%20Way | accessdate = 1 December 2012 }} He attended [[Luther College (Victoria)|Luther College]] in Melbourne's eastern suburbs and graduated from [[Box Hill Senior Secondary College]].{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} ==Music== ===2003-2006: Early Career=== 360 made his first official appearance in 2003 on fellow Australian rapper Infallible's EP ''A Burning Ambition'', on the track "Situation Critical" along with MCs [[Hunter (rapper)|Hunter]] and Versa. The following year, he released his debut solo EP, titled ''Rarities'', in which three of its four tracks featured his rap partner and best friend [[Pez (musician)|Pez]]. In 2005, Pez and 360 released a song called "Nutcase", which 360 described as a "fuck around track [that was] written and recorded in one day. Trying to make you laugh, or cringe". 360 was featured on Sydney producers Weapon X and Ken Hell's 2006 mixtape ''Scar-Non III: Kick To The Head'' with the song "In Da Chub", a remix of [[50 Cent]]'s 2003 hit [[In da Club|"In Da Club"]]. ===2007–2012: ''What You See Is What You Get'', ''Falling & Flying''=== In February 2007, he signed to Soulmate Records.{{cite web|url=http://soulmaterecords.wordpress.com/artists/ |title=Soulmate Records Artist Profiles |publisher=Soulmate Records |accessdate=13 December 2010}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.grounduphiphop.com/2007/02/04/360-signs-with-soulmate-records/ |title=360 signs with Soulmate Records |publisher=Ground Up Hip-Hop |date=4 February 2007 |accessdate=27 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070921181046/http://www.grounduphiphop.com/2007/02/04/360-signs-with-soulmate-records/ |archivedate=21 September 2007 }} He released his debut album, ''What You See Is What You Get'', on 22 March 2008. An ''InTheMix'' reviewer found 360 "not only showcases his hilariously funny comedic side but demonstrates his ability to approach more serious and personal issues, producing a well rounded album".{{cite news | url = http://www.inthemix.com.au/whatson/melbourne/event/44096/360_What_You_See_Is_What_You_Get_Album_Launch | title = 360 ''What You See Is What You Get'' Album Launch | work = InTheMix | publisher = [[Sound Alliance]] | date = 12 April 2008 | accessdate = 2 December 2012 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130927015013/http://www.inthemix.com.au/whatson/melbourne/event/44096/360_What_You_See_Is_What_You_Get_Album_Launch | archive-date = 27 September 2013 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} In a video interview for ''Peak Street Magazine'', 360 described his musical style as a combination of "some [[pop music|pop]] influences, [[electro (music)|electro]], [[dubstep]], and unintelligent rhymes".{{cite web | last=James | first=Sam | title=360 Interview with ''Peak Street'' | url=http://peakstreet.com/post/9094918957/360-vs-peak-street-interview | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130131061052/http://peakstreet.com/post/9094918957/360-vs-peak-street-interview | dead-url=yes | archive-date=31 January 2013 | work=Peak Street Magazine | accessdate=2 December 2012 | first2=Danny | last2=Haneman | first3=Aisha | last3=Glen | date=19 June 2011 }} On 14 January 2008, 360 released a music video of "Mamma Mia", which depicts his desire for [[Bec Hewitt]] and mocked her husband, [[Lleyton Hewitt]], which was the Video of the Week on MySpace.com's Australian hip hop page.{{Cite news | url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/song-slams-trophy-wife-bec/story-e6frf96x-1111115315578 | title=Rapper 360 makes Bec Hewitt lustful object of lyrics | publisher=[[The Herald and Weekly Times]] ([[News Corporation]]) |work=[[Herald Sun]] | date=14 January 2008 | accessdate=27 April 2011 }}{{Cite news | url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/rapper-360-targets-bec-and-lleyton-hewitt-in-myspace-video/story-e6frewyr-1111115314399 | title=Rapper 360 targets Bec and Lleyton Hewitt in MySpace video | date=14 January 2008 | publisher=[[News Limited]] ([[News Corporation]]) | work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]] | accessdate=27 April 2011 }} 360 described it as a comedic effort, "I wanted to take the piss out of them ... It's not meant to be taken too seriously she's not really my type". Management for the couple dismissed the rapper's effort as "a publicity stunt". By March 2010, he remained signed with Soulmate Records, which had signed a distribution deal with [[EMI Records]].{{cite web | url=http://soulmaterecords.wordpress.com/2010/03/15/soulmate-records-x-emi-partnership// |title=Soulmate Records partners with EMI |publisher=Soulmate Records | date=15 March 2010 | accessdate=13 December 2010 }} In December that year, his single, "Just Got Started" (featuring [[Pez (musician)|Pez]]), was released.{{cite web | url = https://itunes.apple.com/nz/album/just-got-started-feat.-pez/id406702982 | title = 'Just Got Started' (feat. Pez) – Single by 360 | work = [[iTunes]] | publisher = [[Apple Inc.]] | date = 17 December 2010 | accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} By March the following year, it peaked at No. 59 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Singles Chart]], and at No. 21 on the ARIA Urban Singles Chart.{{cite web|url=http://www.themusicnetwork.com/music-news/industry/2011/04/04/chart-wrap-up-britney-beats-radiohead-to-1/ |title=Chart Wrap Up Britney Beats Radiohead To 1 |publisher=The Music Network |accessdate=26 April 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20110530-1606/Issue1099.pdf|title=The ARIA Report – 21 March 2011 |publisher=Australian Recording Industry Association |accessdate=30 March 2012}} 360's second album, ''[[Falling & Flying]]'', was released on 30 September 2011{{Cite news|url=http://www.cairns.com.au/article/2011/01/13/144105_entertainment.html|title=360 is flying and falling...|publisher=[[The Cairns Post]]|date=13 January 2011|last=Kuch|first=Jesse|accessdate=27 April 2011}} which reached No. 4 on the ARIA Albums Chart,{{cite web | url = http://www.australian-charts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=360 | title = Discography 360 | publisher = Australian Charts Portal. Hung Medien (Steffen Hung) | last = Hung | first = Steffen | accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} and remained in the number-one position of the Australian [[iTunes]] charts for three weeks. By October 2012, ''Falling & Flying'' was certified platinum by ARIA for shipments of 70,000 units,{{Cite certification|region=Australia|type=album|certyear=2012| accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} and was certified double platinum by July 2014.{{cite web|author1=James Jennings|title=360: Alive and Kicking|url=http://rollingstoneaus.com/music/post/360-alive-and-kicking|website=Rolling Stone Australia|publisher=Rolling Stone|accessdate=21 October 2014|date=2 July 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021113403/http://rollingstoneaus.com/music/post/360-alive-and-kicking|archive-date=21 October 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In November 2011, the fourth single from the album, "Boys like You" (featuring Gossling), was released, which peaked at No. 3 on the Australian singles chart in February 2012. The track also reached the top 40 of the [[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand|New Zealand Singles Chart]].{{cite web | url = http://charts.org.nz/showinterpret.asp?interpret=360 | title = Discography 360 | publisher = New Zealand Charts Portal. Hung Medien (Steffen Hung) | last = Hung | first = Steffen | accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} The single was certified 4× platinum by ARIA for shipments of 280,000 units.{{Cite certification|region=Australia|type=single|certyear=2012| accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} His following singles, "Child" (April 2012) and "Run Alone" (August), both reached the ARIA 'Singles Top 30' chart. "Child" was certified platinum and "Run Alone" received a gold certification. The national Australian "Flying Tour" occurred in support of the album, and 360 was supported by new Melbourne artist Bam Bam.{{cite web|title=Bam Bam|url=https://www.triplejunearthed.com/artist/bam-bam|website=triple j Unearthed|publisher=ABC|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=3 June 2013}} ===2012–present: ''Utopia'' & ''Vintage Modern''=== In June 2012, 360 revealed to national youth broadcaster [[Triple J]] that he was already working on his third album, describing the upcoming release as "quite a dark album". He described it further, "No one sees behind the scenes and there's been a lot of bad (expletive) going on in my family life and personal life". 360 hinted at a diverse production line-up for the album, saying he has "been getting a gang of beats from all different people".{{cite web|title=360 readies "dark" new album|url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s3518538.htm|website=triple j|publisher=ABC|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=5 June 2012}} A video, published on 21 November 2013, served as the official press release for the launch of Forthwrite Records, a music label created by 360 and Pez. 360 then confirmed the announcement on his Facebook page the following day, stating that the label will release ''Don't Look Down'', by Pez, ''[[Utopia (360 album)|Utopia]]'', by 360, and the debut, yet untitled Forthwrite album.{{cite web|author1=360|title=22 November 2013|url=https://en-gb.facebook.com/3ree6ixty/posts/10153511253795367|website=360 on Facebook|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=22 November 2013}}{{cite web|title=FORTHWRITE RECORDS Media Release 21 Nov 2013|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TRkQ8OvXr3A|website=FORTHWRITE on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=2 November 2014|format=Video upload|date=21 November 2013}} During his performance at the 2013 Sprung Hip Hop Festival, held in [[Brisbane]], Australia, 360 garnered media attention for the manner in which he introduced a new song titled "On A Planet No One Knows". According to 360, the song, which also features a vocal sample from [[Joss Whedon]] regarding gender equality, is "about racism in Australia."{{cite web|title=WATCH: 360 – 'On A Planet No One Knows’|url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/tv/watch-360-on-a-planet-no-one-knows/|website=Music Feeds|publisher=Music Feeds|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=2014}} 360 exclaimed:
There's a lot of racist cunts in this country [Australia]. I don't know if people are proud to admit it, or what—but there is. No matter what colour or background we are, there are fuckheads in every single race. Generalising everyone is fucking ignorant and uneducated and stupid. If you're offended by this then you're probably fuckin' racist and you should fuck off.{{cite web|author1=Mike Hohnen|title=360 Calls Out Racist Australia During New Song At Sprung Hip Hop Festival|url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/news/360-calls-out-racist-australia-during-new-song-at-sprung-hip-hop-festival/|website=Music Feeds|publisher=Music Feeds|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=7 October 2013}}
In February 2014, 360 supported the Australian tour of American rapper [[Eminem]], alongside [[Kendrick Lamar]]. 360 described the tour as a career highlight and explained to the media in January 2014 that it would be his first tour sober—he had previously struggled with drug addiction.{{cite news|author1=Lisa Visentin|title=360 announces tour of Australia|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/360-announces-tour-of-australia-20140527-zrpdp.html|accessdate=20 October 2014|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=27 May 2014}} Prior to the release of the artist's third album, ''Utopia'', on 13 June 2014, three singles were released: "Impossible", "On A Planet No One Knows" and "Sixavelli". "Impossible" is a collaboration with [[Daniel Johns]], of Australian band [[Silverchair]], and Johns also appears in the music video, in which he is a passenger in a car driven by 360.{{cite web|title=360 - Impossible (Ft Daniel Johns) Official Video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xU78NDpJt08|website=3ree6ixty on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=20 October 2014|format=Video upload|date=16 January 2014}} A music video was also released for the second single and was published on the artist's YouTube channel during the week before [[Australia Day]].{{cite web|title=360 - ON A PLANET NO ONE KNOWS|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qUWJZSbGF7s|website=3ree6ixty on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=20 October 2014|format=Video upload|date=21 January 2014}} The music video for "Sixavelli" was directed by Claudia Sangiorgi Dalimore and was published in March 2014.{{cite web|title=360 - Sixavelli (Feat. Lunar C)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IN3DtQ_aCFI&list=UUHe7RBRU1OHq0h_Yb4VTUeg|website=3ree6ixty on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=20 October 2014|format=Video upload|date=25 March 2014}} Alongside fellow Australian hip hop act [[Hilltop Hoods]], 360 performed at the 2014 [[Splendour In The Grass]] festival, held in [[Byron Bay]], Australia.{{cite web|title=Splendour In The Grass 2014 lineup|url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s3990250.htm|website=triple j|publisher=ABC|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=23 April 2014}} The Australian "Utopia Tour" occurred during September 2014 and 360 was supported by US rapper Hopsin, UK artist Lunar C, Pez and Miracle.{{cite web|author1=Jed Ahern|title=360 ANNOUNCES UTOPIA TOUR SUPPORT ACTS|url=http://www.vmusic.com.au/news/360-announces-utopia-tour-support-acts.aspx|website=V Music|publisher=Foxtel Management Pty Ltd|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140923110500/http://www.vmusic.com.au/news/360-announces-utopia-tour-support-acts.aspx|archive-date=23 September 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Collaborations== During the early years of his music career, 360 collaborated with Pez as part of a duo called "Forthwrite",{{cite web|title=ForthWrite - 'Guilty Conscience'|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GDxVFtjCxyI|website=PEZ on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=2 November 2014|format=Video upload|date=June 2011}} including a track called "The Club Song" on the 2010 album ''[[Good Gracious]]'', by producer [[M-Phazes]].{{cite web|title=Good Gracious M-Phazes|url=https://itunes.apple.com/nz/album/good-gracious/id359623656|website=iTunes Preview|publisher=Apple Inc|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=26 February 2010}} 360 also featured on Pez's 2008 single, "The Festival Song", which peaked at No. 14 on the ARIA Australian Singles Chart.{{cite web | url = http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20090120-0000/issue985.pdf | title = ARIA Report – 12th Jan 2009 | publisher = Australian Recording Industry Association | issue = 985 | format = [[Portable Document Format|PDF]] | date = 12 January 2009 | accessdate = 2 December 2012}} In 2010, 360 started an online musical project in the Australian hip hop scene, called "Rapper Tag", on YouTube.{{cite web |url=http://www.rappertag.com:80/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712043422/http://www.rappertag.com/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 July 2012 |title=Rapper Tag |publisher=360 |accessdate=4 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Rapper Tag involves one person recording a portion of rap over a looped beat, and then nominating ("tagging") another person to add further rapping over the same loop. The process continued in accordance with the nomination of the next rapper.{{cite web | url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s3076379.htm |title=Triple J: 360 Rapper Tag Phenomenon |accessdate=26 April 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://www.optimising.com.au/blog/interview-on-social-media-with-melbourne-rapper-360/|date=9 March 2011|author=Daniel |title=Interview on Social Media with Melbourne Rapper 360 |accessdate=9 March 2011}} Australian hip hop duo [[Diafrix]] collaborated with 360 for the song "I'm A Dreamer", which appears on the 2012 album ''Pocket Full Of Dreams''.{{cite web|title=Diafrix feat. 360 - I'm A Dreamer (Official Video)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JXTRCDRkz34|website=diafrix lion on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=2 November 2014|format=Video upload|date=June 2012}} 360 appeared on the self-titled debut album by Canberra producer, Ghosts in the Room, released on 14 September 2012 through Mudd Music. The album also features rappers Iron Solomon, Okwerdz and Kool G Rap.{{cite web|title=Ghosts in the Room Ghosts in the Room|url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/ghosts-in-the-room/id537506609|website=iTunes Preview|publisher=Apple Inc|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=14 September 2012}} ==Media appearances== 360 was a panel member for the 20 October 2014 edition of the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] (ABC) program ''[[Q&A (Australian talk show)|Q&A]]''. He appeared alongside [[Brian Cox (physicist)|Brian Cox]], a particle physicist, [[Richard Gill (conductor)|Richard Gill]], renowned conductor, and [[Nalini Joshi]], a notable Australian mathematician, to discuss the topic of "passion".{{cite web|author1=gregmoskovitch|title=Get The Popcorn, 360 Is A Panelist On Next Monday's Q&A|url=http://www.tonedeaf.com.au/421594/360-will-appear-next-mondays-qa.htm|website=Tone Deaf|publisher=Tone Deaf|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=15 October 2014}} 360 garnered media attention for his comments on the television program regarding racism in relation to Australia, Australian hip hop and the Australian flag. When questioned by the presenter, 360 replied:
On Australia Day, you see dudes walking around with their tops off, and they're getting on the drink and all that. And they've got an Australian flag wrapped around their neck. I've seen it so many times; like, I've been in a taxi where we've pulled up because these dickheads have been walking across the road—they just start yelling at the taxi driver, like: "Get out of the country! This is not your country!" ... And they're wearing Australian flags. I've seen it so much, like, growing up ... still today, you know what I mean?{{cite web|title=Australian flag represents racism: 360|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dndT4vq5CpE|website=ABC News (Australia) on YouTube|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=21 October 2014|format=Video upload|date=20 October 2014}}
This response caused controversy,{{cite news|title=#BBCTrending: Has Australia's flag been co-opted by racists?|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-trending-29712614|accessdate=27 October 2014|work=BBC News|date=21 October 2014}} including the transference of the media spotlight onto Pez, who made comments on social media following 360's appearance. In addition to a message of support for his friend and musical collaborator, Pez also wrote that he also "got a bit offended"; however, he subsequently removed the sentence "To be honest, even I got a bit offended." from his original Facebook post. As of 24 October 2014, 360 had not retracted his ''Q&A'' comments and explained after the airing of the episode: "If you are not racist then you have nothing to be offended about."{{cite web|author1=Nastassia Baroni|title=Pez Admits To Being "Offended" By 360's 'Q&A' Comments|url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/news/pez-admits-to-being-offended-by-360s-qa-comments/|website=Music Feeds|publisher=Music Feeds|accessdate=2 November 2014|date=24 October 2014}} ==Personal life== {{outdated section|date=September 2016}} At the age of 18 years, 360 contracted a disease of his right eye, a [[cornea transplant]], which "left him with fuzzy vision" in that eye. A July 2014 feature article in ''Rolling Stone Australia'' stated that he is "legally blind in his right eye", while his left eye is "slowly deteriorating due to the degenerative eye disease Keratoconus". On 18 July 2010, 360 was involved in a [[go-kart]]ing accident while celebrating his birthday with Sydney-based hip hop artists [[Bliss n Eso]]. He suffered a torn [[artery]], lacerated [[pancreas]] and a damaged [[scrotum]].{{cite web|last=Adams|first=Cameron|title=Accident brings 360 perspective|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/accident-brings-360-perspective/story-e6frfn09-1226152049520|work=news.com.au| publisher = News Limited (News Corporation) | date = 29 September 2011 |accessdate=14 April 2012}} According to the rapper, "It [scrotum] wasn't ruptured, but it was ripped open ... The first thing I checked once I woke up was I didn't need to use a colostomy bag. My sex life is intact. There's no sex appeal if you use a colostomy bag". On 13 February 2012, 360 and Crystal Bale became engaged;{{cite web|title=Rapper 360 Is Engaged To Crystal Bale!|url=http://www.take40.com/news/29098/rapper-360-is-engaged-to-crystal-bale!|work=take40.com|accessdate=18 May 2012}}{{cite web|title=360 Is Engaged!|url=http://www.novafm.com.au/article/360-engaged|work=novafm.com.au|accessdate=18 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504133510/http://www.novafm.com.au/article/360-engaged|archive-date=4 May 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} the pair then separated on 24 December 2012.{{cite web|title=@crystallouu|url=https://twitter.com/crystallouu/status/283034663667257345|accessdate=31 December 2012}}{{cite web|title=360 degrees of separation for rapper 360 and fiancee Crystal Bale |url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/degrees-of-separation-for-rapper-360-and-fiancee-crystal-bale/story-e6frewz0-1226543747857|accessdate=31 December 2012}} As of October 2014, 360 is listed as a supporter of the 'Oscar's Law' campaign, which seeks to raise public awareness about the detrimental effects of factory farming of companion animals.{{cite web|title=Home|url=http://www.oscarslaw.org/|work=Oscar's law|publisher=Oscar's Law|accessdate=13 October 2012|author=Debra Tranter|year=2010}} He also appeared in [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]]'s 'Ink not Mink' anti-fur campaign."[http://music.ninemsn.com.au/blog.aspx?blogentryid=1196723&showcomments=true Ink Not Mink! Rapper 360 Flashes His Tatts for PETA's Anti-Fur Campaign,"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606033913/http://music.ninemsn.com.au/blog.aspx?blogentryid=1196723&showcomments=true |date=6 June 2014 }} ninemsn.com.au, 2 June 2014. 360 and Bale promoted awareness of suicide and depression issues. In mid-February 2012, he posted a video clip with the following statement: "I don't usually drop serious videos, but this is something I'm passionate about spreading awareness about. Even if you hate me, this has nothing to do with music—please share this around so as many people as possible can see it".{{cite web|title=Rapper 360 Speaks Out About Suicide |url=http://www.take40.com/artists/5752/360/news/29226/watch:-rapper-360-speaks-out-about-suicide |work=take40.com |accessdate=1 December 2012 }} In September 2012, Bale posted her video, 'A Message from Crystal', which Beats Factory{{'}}s Robyn Morrison described as footage of Bale "talking about how she has been affected by suicide—multiple times ... [it] is sometimes hard to watch, but essential viewing".{{cite news | url = http://www.beatsfactory.com.au/360s-fiancee-opens-about-suicide | title = 360's Fiancée Opens Up About Suicide | last = Morrison | first = Robyn | work = Beats Factory | date = 16 September 2012 | accessdate = 2 December 2012 | archive-url = https://archive.is/20130114235912/http://www.beatsfactory.com.au/360s-fiancee-opens-about-suicide | archive-date = 14 January 2013 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }} On 8 January 2016, 360 posted a song named ''I'm Sorry'' onto his [[Facebook]] page. It talked about his [[codeine]] addiction. His addiction resulted in him cancelling tours without notice. In the song 360 mentions how he didn't tell anyone because he felt like a burden. Because he was addicted to [[Nurofen Plus]], the pills could be bought without a prescription.{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/melbourne-rapper-360-explains-how-prescription-drugs-almost-killed-him/news-story/1c867df0f625977f7dffcc8d63d8a08d|title=Melbourne rapper 360 explains how prescription drugs almost killed him|date=11 January 2016|access-date=16 January 2016|website=[[news.com.au]]|first1=Rohan|last1=Smith}}{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/music-videos/rappers-brutally-honest-painkiller-addiction-confession/news-story/b2e5a9077fe976f15716bba1630e10ee|title=Rapper’s brutally honest painkiller addiction confession|website=[[news.com.au]]|first=Emma|last=Reynolds}} In September 2016, 360 announced that he was diagnosed with [[unipolar depression]].{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/rapper-360s-candid-facebook-post-about-his-breakdown/news-story/0aeeb73b6e1f862c364e5e93b94d459a|title=Rapper 360 opens up about depression with heartbreaking post|publisher=|accessdate=22 September 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3797575/Rapper-360-reveals-struggle-unipolar-depression-heart-wrenching-essay.html|title=Rapper 360 reveals his struggle with unipolar depression.|publisher=|accessdate=22 September 2016}} ==Accolades and awards== ===2011=== "Boys like You" was voted into the No. 8 position in the [[Triple J Hottest 100, 2011|Triple J Hottest 100 countdown of 2011]].{{cite web | url = http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/hottest100/11/fulllist.htm | title = Hottest 100 – 2011 Countdown, Full List | publisher = [[Triple J]], [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] (ABC) | accessdate = 2 December 2012 }} Also that year, 360 was awarded the [[Channel V|Channel [V]]] 'Oz Artist of the Year', ahead of [[Guy Sebastian]] and [[Short Stack]],[http://ozartist.vmusic.com.au/ Oz Artist of the Year 2011 Entrants] {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/6BPGPChYD?url=http://ozartist.vmusic.com.au/ |date=14 October 2012 }}. vmusic.com.au and received the 'Jägermeister Most Hunted Award' at the [[Jägermeister]] Independent Music Awards [[Australian Independent Record Labels Association|(Australian Independent Record (AIR) Awards)]], which is voted by fans.[http://ausindies.com.au/id-2011-awards.html The Winners] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403224000/http://ausindies.com.au/id-2011-awards.html |date=3 April 2012 }}, Australian Independent Record Labels Association Ltd (AIR), 2012 ===2012=== At the 2012 AIR Awards, 360 won the 'Best Independent Hip Hop Album' award for ''Falling & Flying''.{{cite web|title=WINNERS ANNOUNCED – 2012 JAGERMEISTER INDEPENDENT MUSIC AWARDS|url=http://www.air.org.au/news/winners-announced-2012-jagermeister-independent-music-awards/|work=Australian Independent Record Labels Association|publisher=AIR|accessdate=18 October 2012|date=17 October 2012}} ===ARIA Awards=== At the [[ARIA Music Awards of 2012]], 360 was nominated in six categories and won the 'ARIA Award for Breakthrough Artist - Release' for ''Falling & Flying'', while Feugo won the 'Producer of the Year' in the Artisan section.{{Cite web |url=http://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/year/2012 |title=2012 ARIA Awards Winners By Year |publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA) |accessdate=30 November 2012 }} {{Awards Urban Album|Best Urban Album]] || {{nom}} |- | [[ARIA Award for Breakthrough Artist - Release|Breakthrough Artist – Release]] || {{won}} |- | ''Falling & Flying'' – 360 || [[ARIA Award for Best Male {{update|date=February 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = A-Trak | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | image = | caption = A-Trak in Rajesh | birth_name = Alain Macklovitch | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1982|3|30}} | origin = [[Montréal, Quebec|Montréal]], [[Quebec]], Canada | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Electro house]]<ref>{{cite news|first= Brian |last= Mansfield |url= http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/LIFE/usaedition/2012-07-17-the-Verge-with-Kimbra_ST_U.htm |title= Thanks to Gotye, she is 'Somebody' |newspaper= [[USA Today]] |quote= The single ''Warrior'' (...) features Canadian electro-house DJ A-Trak and Foster the People's Mark Foster. |date= 16 July 2012 |accessdate= 28 September 2014}}</ref> * [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] }} | occupation = [[DJ]], [[Record producer|producer]], label executive, [[turntablist]] | years_active = 1997–present | label = [[Fool's Gold Records|Fool's Gold]] | associated_acts = {{flatlist| * [[Low Pros]] * [[Kanye West]] * [[Lupe Fiasco]] * [[Boys Noize]] * [[Kid Cudi]] * [[Armand Van Helden]] * [[Jay-Z]] * [[Juicy J]] * [[Danny Brown (rapper)|Danny Brown]] * [[DJ Craze]] * [[Kid Sister]] * [[Travis Barker]] * [[Duck Sauce (band)|Duck Sauce]] * [[Kimbra]] * [[Jamie Lidell]] * [[Run–D.M.C.]] * [[The Roots]] * [[Andrew Wyatt]] * [[Zhu (musician)|Zhu]] }} | website = {{official website|http://www.atrak.com}} }}
'''Alain Macklovitch''' (born March 30, 1982), known by his stage name '''A-Trak''', is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[Disc jockey|DJ]], [[turntablist]], record producer, and music label executive. He is the owner of the [[record label]] [[Fool's Gold Records|Fool's Gold]] which was founded in 2007, and is credited for developing the careers of artists such as [[Kid Cudi]], [[Danny Brown (rapper)|Danny Brown]], and [[Flosstradamus]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://windishagency.com/artists/atrak|title=The Windish Agency: A-Trak|website=windishagency.com|access-date=2016-06-14}}</ref> A-Trak's career has spanned nearly two decades, leading ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' to name him one of the 50 Most Important People in EDM.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/50-most-important-people-in-edm-20140317/a-trak-19691231|title=A-Trak - 50 Most Important People in EDM|website=Rolling Stone|access-date=2016-06-14}}</ref> A-Trak is also part of the DJ duo [[Duck Sauce]] with [[Armand Van Helden]], which was nominated for a Grammy in 2012 for their song [[Barbra Streisand (song)|"Barbra Streisand"]]. A-Trak was featured on the covers of ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/507766/skrillex-diplo-a-trak-the-billboard-cover-story|title=Skrillex, Diplo & A-Trak: The Billboard Cover Story|website=Billboard|access-date=2016-06-14}}</ref> and ''[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]'' and recently appeared in campaigns for [[Adidas]],<ref>{{Citation|last=adidas Originals|title=adidas Originals {{!}} Unite All Originals|date=2013-08-01|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8fr1ZuPcQSo&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2016-06-14}}</ref> [[Grey Goose (vodka)|Grey Goose]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vibe.com/2012/08/exclusive-video-atrak-pops-grey-goose-cherry-hotel-noir/|title=Exclusive Video! A-Trak Pops His Grey Goose Cherry in Hotel Noir|date=2012-08-22|website=Vibe|access-date=2016-06-14}}</ref> [[Converse (shoe company)|Converse]] and [[Cadillac]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.highsnobiety.com/2014/04/15/cadillac-a-trak-new-crest-2015-ats-coupe/|title=Cadillac Partners with A-Trak to Introduce its New Crest and 2015 ATS Coupe|date=2014-04-15|website=Highsnobiety|access-date=2016-06-14}}</ref> A-Trak has also penned a number of articles for ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' and owns the travel website Infinite Legroom. After residing in [[Brooklyn]] for many years, he now calls [[Los Angeles]] home.
== Career ==
=== Early career === Macklovitch was born to Moroccan Jewish Mother and Russian Jewish father in [[Montréal, Quebec]]. When he was 18 years old, his mother took him and his brother back to Morocco to connect with their roots. His older brother, David Macklovitch, is one-half of the electro-funk duo [[Chromeo]].
A-Trak was the first DJ to win all three major DJ competition titles ([[Disco Mix Club|DMC]], ITF and [[Vestax]]), as well as being the first DJ to win five World Championships.<ref>{{cite web|title=A-Trak Bio, Music, News & Shows|url=http://djz.com/featured_djs/a-trak/|publisher=DJZ.com|accessdate=March 6, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130329044955/http://djz.com/featured_djs/a-trak/|archive-date=March 29, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> He won the [[Disco Mix Club|DMC World DJ Championship]] in 1997 at the age of 15, making him the youngest and first Canadian winner of the competition.<ref>{{cite web|title=1997 World DJ Champion – A-Trak (Canada) |url=http://www.dmcdjchamps.com/worldchamps.asp |work=[[Disco Mix Club]] |accessdate=Oct 1, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090523075622/http://www.dmcdjchamps.com/worldchamps.asp |archivedate=May 23, 2009 }}</ref> He was an honorary member of the now defunct DJ crew [[Invisibl Skratch Piklz]],<ref name="Rane">{{cite web |title=A-Trak |url=http://www.rane.com/dj/atrak.html |work=[[Rane Corp.]] |accessdate=Oct 1, 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070817040111/http://www.rane.com/dj/atrak.html|archivedate=August 17, 2007 }}</ref> and a member of The Allies alongside frequent collaborator [[DJ Craze]].<ref>{{cite web |title=4idols.com DJ A-Trak Bio, Photo Gallery, and Videos |url=http://www.4idols.com/d/dj-a-trak.htm |work=4idols.com |publisher=MadCool Network LLC |accessdate=Oct 1, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091218060705/http://www.4idols.com/d/dj-a-trak.htm |archive-date=December 18, 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In the late 90's A-Trak developed a notation system for scratching.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spinscience.org.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=38&Itemid=50 |title=Online Turntable Music Resource – A-trak |publisher=Spin Science |date=19 November 2004 |accessdate=2010-05-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080216054321/http://www.spinscience.org.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=38&Itemid=50 |archive-date=February 16, 2008 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> He gave a lecture about it at the Skratchcon 2000 conference and published an article in ''Tablist'' Magazine.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/871390/invisibl-skratch-piklz-to-host-turntablist-conference/|title=Invisibl Skratch Piklz To Host Turntablist Conference|newspaper=MTV News|access-date=2016-12-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.urbansmarts.com/interviews/audioresearch.htm|title=:: urban smarts . com {{!}} audio research artists' a-trak, dj serious, dj simahlak {{!}} interview ::|website=www.urbansmarts.com|access-date=2016-12-01}}</ref> He has also appeared on the cover of multiple magazines including ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'', ''[[URB (magazine)|URB]]'' (twice), ''[[BPM (magazine)|BPM]]'' and ''Status''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://djatrak.com/2012/02/05/cover-of-billboard-magazine/ |title=A-Trak : Fat-free since 1982! » Blog Archive » Cover of Billboard Magazine! |publisher=Djatrak.com |date=5 February 2012 |accessdate=2012-02-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120424025409/http://djatrak.com/2012/02/05/cover-of-billboard-magazine/ |archive-date=April 24, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://djatrak.com/2009/05/12/cover-of-status-magazine/ |title=A-Trak : Fat-free since 1982! » Blog Archive » Cover of Status magazine |publisher=Djatrak.com |date=12 May 2009 |accessdate=2010-05-12 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100402072533/http://djatrak.com/2009/05/12/cover-of-status-magazine/ |archivedate=April 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
A-Trak and his brother Dave ran the record label Audio Research from 1997–2007.<ref>[http://www.sandboxautomatic.com/audioresearch/ Audio Research Records] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050901161548/http://www.sandboxautomatic.com/audioresearch/ |date=September 1, 2005 }}</ref> After moving to Williamsburg, he founded the label [[Fool's Gold Records]] with Nick Catchdubs in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foolsgoldrecs.com/ |title=Fool'S Gold |publisher=Foolsgoldrecs.com |accessdate=2010-05-12| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100511072449/http://foolsgoldrecs.com/| archivedate= May 11, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
=== Kanye West === A-Trak had been booked to play a show, in 2004 at a tiny record shop in London. [[Kanye West]] came to support [[John Legend]] who was also playing in the same show.<ref>{{cite web|title=Before Leaping Onto Kanye's Records, A-Trak Forged A Career From Scratch|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/05/14/477850354/before-leaping-onto-kanyes-records-a-trak-forged-a-career-from-scratch|website=Npr.com|accessdate=8 September 2016}}</ref> In 2004, [[Kanye West]] recruited A-Trak as his personal tour DJ,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newyork.joonbug.com/frequency/featured-artist-profile-atrak-frequency-new-york/xcN90nPl4f5 |title=Featured Artist Profile: A-Trak : Frequency New York |publisher=Newyork.joonbug.com |accessdate=2010-05-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703062112/http://newyork.joonbug.com/frequency/featured-artist-profile-atrak-frequency-new-york/xcN90nPl4f5 |archive-date=July 3, 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and he has worked closely with him ever since, including performances alongside the rapper at MTV specials, the [[Grammy Awards]], multiple [[MTV Video Music Awards]], and worldwide stadium shows. A-Trak also recorded scratches on Kanye West's second and third studio albums ''[[Late Registration]]'' (2005) and ''[[Graduation (album)|Graduation]]'' (2007) and was an influence on the overall sound of the latter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hardfest.com/atrak.php |title=A-Trak : : HARD New Year's Eve : December 31st, 2009 |publisher=Hardfest.com |date=31 December 2009 |accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref> [[File:Kanye West in Portland.jpg|thumb|right|190px|Kanye West performing backed by A-Trak in [[Portland, Oregon]], 2005]] Over the years he has endorsed several brands including Serato [[Scratch Live]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.serato.com/artists/atrak |title=Artists – A-Trak |publisher=Serato.com |accessdate=2010-05-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091001193044/http://www.serato.com/artists/atrak |archive-date=October 1, 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and [[Rane Corp.|Rane DJ equipment]].<ref name="Rane" />
He is known for merging the sounds of rap and electronic music through his remix work, his 2007 CD ''Dirty South Dance'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.residentadvisor.net/review-view.aspx?id=4518 |title=RA Reviews: A-Trak – Dirty South Dance (Album) |publisher=Residentadvisor.net |accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref> his production for [[Kid Sister]] and [[Lupe Fiasco]], and his remixes for electronic artists including [[MSTRKRFT]] and [[Boys Noize]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/A-Trak |title=A-Trak Discography at Discogs |publisher=Discogs.com |accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref> However, some of his production displays a separation of his electronic and hip hop identities, with releases such as "Piss Test" featuring Juicy J and collaborations with Tommy Trash on "Tuna Melt".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.highsnobiety.com/2010/10/14/music-a-trak-feat-cyhi-da-prynce-ray-ban-vision/|title=Music: A-Trak Feat. CyHi Da Prynce "Ray Ban Vision"|date=2010-10-15|website=Highsnobiety|access-date=2016-12-01}}</ref> Another hip hop production, "Ray Ban Vision", was used in the 2012 movie [[Project X (2012 film)|Project X]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2016}}
In 2009, A-Trak collaborated with [[Armand Van Helden]] to form a disco house production duo under the name [[Duck sauce (band)|Duck Sauce]]. They released the song "[[Anyway (Duck Sauce song)|Anyway]]" in October on [[Ministry of Sound]]. Duck Sauce has achieved success worldwide including reaching the top chart position in twelve countries and attaining the #1 spot on the US Dance [[Billboard charts]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2016}} Following the announcement of a debut album, Duck Sauce released the singles "It's You" and "Radio Stereo".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dancingastronaut.com/2013/10/duck-sauce-unveil-radio-stereo-second-single-from-upcoming-quack-album|title=Duck Sauce unveil 'Radio Stereo,' second single from upcoming 'Quack' album - Dancing Astronaut|website=www.dancingastronaut.com|access-date=2016-12-01}}</ref>
In February 2010, it was announced that A-Trak would perform live shows with [[Travis Barker]], who had previously worked with their mutual friend, the late [[DJ AM]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Montgomery |first=James |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1632005/20100216/barker__travis.jhtml |title=Travis Barker, A-Trak Talk About Their New Project, Tour – News Story | Music, Celebrity, Artist News | MTV News |work=Mtv |date=17 February 2010 |accessdate=2010-05-12| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100403022410/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1632005/20100216/barker__travis.jhtml| archivedate= April 3, 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> On June 8 of that year, A-Trak released his wildly successful remix of the [[Yeah Yeah Yeahs|Yeah Yeah Yeahs']] track "Heads Will Roll", which was also featured on the [[Project X (2012 film)]] soundtrack.
In 2012, A-Trak was featured on the cover of ''Billboard'' Magazine alongside [[Diplo (DJ)|Diplo]] and [[Skrillex]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/507766/skrillex-diplo-a-trak-the-billboard-cover-story |title=Skrillex, Diplo & A-Trak: The Billboard Cover Story |work=Billboard |accessdate=2012-04-14}}</ref> Also in 2012, A-Trak collaborated with [[Kimbra]] and [[Mark Foster (musician)|Mark Foster]] on a song, entitled "[[Warrior (Kimbra song)|Warrior]]", for [[Converse (shoe company)|Converse]]'s ''3 Artists, 1 song''.
In February 2013, A-Trak released the video for his "Piss Test" remix off of the [[Fool's Gold Records|Fool's Gold]] album. The video features appearances by [[Jim Jones (rapper)|Jim Jones]], [[Juicy J]], [[A$AP Ferg]], [[El-P]], Flatbush Zombies, and [[Flosstradamus]] and was directed by [[Shomi Patwary]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Minsker|first=Evan|title=Video: A-Trak's "Piss Test" Remix With Jim Jones, Juicy J, El-P, Flatbush Zombies, Flosstradamus|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/49700-video-a-traks-piss-test-remix-with-jim-jones-juicy-j-el-p-flatbush-zombies-flosstradamus/|work=Pitchfork Media|accessdate=26 February 2013}}</ref> A-Trak's video for "Tuna Melt", off of his 'Tuna Melt EP', was nominated in the Best Cinematography category at the 2013 MTV Video Music Awards.<ref>{{cite web|last=Minsker|first=Evan|title=Video: Viral A-Trak 'Tuna Melt' video earns MTV VMA nomination for two upstate NY natives|url=http://www.syracuse.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2013/08/viral_a-trak_video_tuna_melt_vma.html|work=Syracuse.com|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref>
=== ''Push'' EP === In January 2014, A-Trak teamed up with [[Cadillac]] in a campaign to introduce their new logo and the 2015 ATS Coup.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.highsnobiety.com/2014/04/15/cadillac-a-trak-new-crest-2015-ats-coupe/|title=Cadillac Partners with A-Trak to Introduce its New Crest and 2015 ATS Coupe|date=2014-04-15|website=Highsnobiety|access-date=2016-06-14}}</ref> On November 25, 2014 A-Trak released his ''Push'' ''EP'', featuring his single "Push" (featuring Andrew Wyatt).
In January 2015, A-Trak was featured on fellow producer [[Diplo]]'s [[BBC Radio 1]] show ''[[Diplo & Friends]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://soundcloud.com/a-trak/a-trak-diplo-friends-january-2015-mix|title=A-Trak - Diplo & Friends January 2015 Mix|website=SoundCloud|access-date=2016-06-14}}</ref>
A-Trak was named as one of the featured artists in the 2015 Renaissance Hotels' music and entertainment program in April 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6707874/renaissance-hotels-music-program-a-trak-awolnation|title=A-Trak, AWOLNATION & The Lone Bellow Head Renaissance Hotels Music Program|website=Billboard|access-date=2016-06-14}}</ref>
On May 4, 2015 A-Trak released his remix of [[Alesso]]'s song "Cool" (featuring Roy English). On May 18, 2015 the ''Push'' remix album was released featuring remixes from [[The Chainsmokers]], [[Cazzette]], [[René LaVice]], [[DallasK]], GANZ, Shash'U PWRFNK, Mak and Pasteman, and Patrick Hagenaar.
A-Trak then began his own weekly two-hour radio show on [[Beats 1]], listened to via [[Apple Music]] Connect, named ''Day Off Radio'' on July 4, 2015.
A-Trak was featured on [[Zhu (musician)]]'s 2015 EP ''Genesis Series'' for his track "As Crazy as It Is" with ZHU and Keznamdi. He was also featured on [[Disclosure (band)]]'s ''Magnets [The Remixes] EP,'' for his remix of "Magnets" (featuring Lorde).
=== We All Fall Down === A-Trak released his EP ''We All Fall Down'' on October 30, 2015 featuring his single "We All Fall Down" (featuring Jamie Lidell), as well as remixes by Volt & State, CID and Jarreau Vandal. On December 11 later that year, the ''We All Fall Down [Remixes] EP'' was released featuring remixes by JayKode, eSQUIRE, Cory Enemy and Syre, Dombresky, STFU, and Willy Joy. A week later on December 18, 2015 A-Trak's "Place on Earth" single with ZooFunktion was released on [[Spinnin' Records]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dancingastronaut.com/2015/11/trak-zoofunktion-place-earth-radio-edit/|title=A-Trak & Zoofunktion - Place On Earth (Radio Edit) - Dancing Astronaut|website=www.dancingastronaut.com|access-date=2016-12-01}}</ref>
A-Trak was featured on the 2016 [[Fool's Gold Records]] compilation album ''Fool's Gold Presents: Night Shift,'' for his song "Only One" with [[Ookay]].
On May 3, 2016 A-Trak premiered his single "Parallel Lines" (featuring [[Phantogram (band)]]) on [[Zane Lowe]]'s [[Beats 1]] Radio show. The ''Parallel Lines [Remixes] EP'' is set to be released on July 1, 2016 and features remixes from [[MSTRKRFT]], Chris Lorenzo, Bart B, Holl & Rush, BLU J, and Doobious.
A-Trak will embark on an Australian Tour with fellow producer [[What So Not]] on June 30, 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sweatitoutmusic.com/not-trak-2016-australia-tour/|title=What So Not & A-Trak 2016 Australia Tour {{!}} Sweat It Out|date=2016-06-08|website=Sweat It Out|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-14}}</ref>
In August 2016 Fool's Gold Day Off, the annual festival put on by [[Fool's Gold Records]], will celebrate its sixth year with shows in [[New York City]], [[Miami]] and [[Los Angeles]].
In 2018, the single "[[Ride for Me]]" was released as a collaboration by A-Trak, Falcons, [[Young Thug]] and 24hrs via A-Trak's record label [[Fool's Gold]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hear-young-thug-a-traks-rowdy-new-song-ride-for-me-w516471 |title=Hear Young Thug, A-Trak's Rowdy New Song 'Ride For Me' |last=Spanos |first=Brittany |website=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=2018-02-08}}</ref>

In 2017, A-Trak was nominated for DJ of the Year at the [[Electronic Music Awards]].
